content.raw:
To run the test: gazebo/build/gazebo/common/UNIT_SVGLoader_TEST

You can cut and paste the output into an html file to see the polylines, but you will need to remove the 4 to 5 gtest lines at both ends (they start with [ ).
If you want to do more tests, add paths into the test/data/loader.svg
content.html:
To run the test: gazebo/build/gazebo/common/UNIT_SVGLoader_TEST

You can cut and paste the output into an html file to see the polylines, but you will need to remove the 4 to 5 gtest lines at both ends (they start with [ ). If you want to do more tests, add paths into the test/data/loader.svg

content.raw:

content.raw:
looks good to me.

minor comments on whether we want to keep consistency with rest of gazebo coding style:

-  throwing exception vs `gzerr` vs assert. It's using `throw` here which is not used often in gazebo.

- static camelCase functions? we do have some static member functions with capitalized first letter and other static functions with underscores so probably we should stick to one or the other?

Maybe @nkoenig can comment on this?
content.html:
looks good to me.

minor comments on whether we want to keep consistency with rest of gazebo coding style:

  • throwing exception vs gzerr vs assert. It's using throw here which is not used often in gazebo.

  • static camelCase functions? we do have some static member functions with capitalized first letter and other static functions with underscores so probably we should stick to one or the other?

Maybe @nkoenig can comment on this?

content.raw: Gazebo is not handling exceptions at program high level so we probably don't want to throw inter-module exceptions. It should be fine to throw them if you are always sure of catch them inside the same module and don't leave users or the rest of gazebo the task of handling them. We usually use gzerr.
content.html: Gazebo is not handling exceptions at program high level so we probably don't want to throw inter-module exceptions. It should be fine to throw them if you are always sure of catch them inside the same module and don't leave users or the rest of gazebo the task of handling them. We usually use gzerr.

content.raw: done, exception should not escape the Parse method
content.html: done, exception should not escape the Parse method

content.raw: Is there any other value possible for name? Maybe makes sense to introduce an `else()` clause displaying an error if all the values were checked in the code above.
content.html: Is there any other value possible for name? Maybe makes sense to introduce an else() clause displaying an error if all the values were checked in the code above.

content.raw: I put warnings for ignored attributes
Is NULL a valid value for _pElement?
changed the switch to an if

is there any reason to implement this sequence of if blocks instead of using a switch? I reimplemented it in 95e851c (`svg_parser_jrivero` branch). Also added a default clause which displays an error if cmd has a non working value.
content.html: is there any reason to implement this sequence of if blocks instead of using a switch? I reimplemented it in 95e851c (svg_parser_jrivero branch). Also added a default clause which displays an error if cmd has a non working value.

content.raw:
Code check warning in utopic:


```
#!c++

[gazebo/common/SVGLoader.cc:426]: (warning) Redundant code: Found a statement that begins with string constant.

```

It looks like cppcheck can't handle this c++11 feature. Can you add a suppression to `codecheck.sh`?

Code check warning in utopic:

[gazebo/common/SVGLoader.cc:426]: (warning) Redundant code: Found a statement that begins with string constant.

It looks like cppcheck can't handle this c++11 feature. Can you add a suppression to codecheck.sh?
